prompt:
I have the following count table for an RNA-seq experiment, rows are genes and columns are samples, "Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx". The first column of the file is my gene names and the rest of the columns are samples. My annotation data is here  "SRP021193.colData.tsv", it contains sample annotations and rows of this matches the columns of count table, first column is the sample ids. Find genes specific for each "group" in my annotation data  using statistical tests. Plot PCA only using "group" specific genes and color code PCA by "group" variable in my annotation data.

response:
To accomplish this task, we will follow the following steps:

1. Read the count table and annotation data.
2. Perform a statistical test to identify genes specific for each group.
3. Plot a PCA using the group-specific genes and color code it by the "group" variable.

Here's the code:

```
# Step 1: Read the count table and annotation data

# Install required libraries, if not already installed





# Load required libraries
library(readxl)
library(dplyr)
library(DESeq2)
library(ggplot2)

# Read the count table
count_table <- read_excel("Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx")

# Read the annotation data
annotation_data <- read.delim("SRP021193.colData.tsv", sep = "\t")

# Step 2: Perform statistical test to identify group-specific genes

# Prepare count table for DESeq2 analysis
rownames(count_table) <- count_table[, 1] # Set gene names as row names
count_table <- count_table[, 2:ncol(count_table)] # Exclude first column with gene names
colnames(count_table) <- colnames(count_table) # Ensure valid column names

# Create DESeq2 object
dds <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = count_table, colData = annotation_data, design = ~ group)

# Perform differential expression analysis
dds <- DESeq(dds)

# Extract results for group-specific genes
res <- results(dds, contrast = c("group", "group1", "group2")) # replace group1 and group2 with your actual group names

# Get significantly differentially expressed genes (p-value < 0.05 and |log2FoldChange| > 1)
group_specific_genes <- subset(res, padj < 0.05 & abs(log2FoldChange) > 1)

# Step 3: Plot PCA using group-specific genes

# Subset count table to include only group-specific genes
group_specific_counts <- count_table[row.names(count_table) %in% row.names(group_specific_genes), ]

# Perform PCA
pca <- prcomp(t(group_specific_counts), scale. = TRUE)

# Get PCA scores
pca_scores <- as.data.frame(pca$x)

# Add group information from annotation data to PCA scores
pca_scores$group <- annotation_data$group

# Plot PCA with color-coded groups
ggplot(pca_scores, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = group)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "PCA Plot", x = "PC1", y = "PC2") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("group1" = "red", "group2" = "blue")) # replace group1 and group2 with your actual group names
```

Make sure to replace `"Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx"` and `"SRP021193.colData.tsv"` with the actual file paths for your count table and annotation data respectively. Also, update `group1` and `group2` with your actual group names in the contrast argument and color scale_color_manual respectively.

This code will perform a statistical test (differential expression analysis) between the groups specified in the annotation data and identify group-specific genes. Then it will plot a PCA using only the group-specific genes and color-code the PCA by the "group" variable in the annotation data.
